Award.AwardTitle: NSF Workshop: New Vistas in Molecular Thermodynamics: Experimentation, Modeling and Inverse Design

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project will support a workshop on Molecular Thermodynamics that will be held on the campus of the University of California-Berkeley, from January 7 to 9, 2018. The workshop will bring together technology leaders and junior researchers to develop a roadmap for basic research in response to emerging opportunities and challenges in the Chemical Process Industries. The workshop will foster debate and discussion among scholars from different areas of the Molecular Thermodynamics community to uncover fundamental research questions whose answers will enable overcoming current technological challenges. It will also will also cover topics related to modernizing Engineering Education. Successful development and implementation of new tools for process design and optimization will ensure sustained competitiveness of the U.S. chemical industry while also addressing environmental challenges and promoting energy efficiency.

Recent trends emphasizing environmental sustainability and improved energy efficiency in the chemical process industries have created new research opportunities in the field of Molecular Thermodynamics. By connecting the physicochemical properties of matter at all length scales, Molecular Thermodynamics has been an enabling tool to accelerate scientific innovations, catalyze emerging technologies, and provide core knowledge for design and optimization of diverse industrial systems, ranging from energy production, materials synthesis, and chemical processing to pharmaceutical and environmental applications. The rapid emergence of new methods in computational algorithms, data science and artificial intelligence provide a unique opportunity for innovation and interdisciplinary collaboration by integrating experimental and computational methods into powerful tools for process design and optimization. In addition to defining new research frontiers in the field of Molecular Thermodynamics, the workshop will also address curriculum development and workforce training issues to ensure continued world-wide competitiveness of the U.S. chemical industry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF workshop brought together a group of promising young researchers and internationally renowned scientists to brainstorm opportunities and challenges in fundamentals and applications of molecular thermodynamics to innovative technologies for sustainable engineering developments that are currently undergoing rapid progress. It identified common interests in the fundamentals of moelcular thermodynamics, enhanced mutual understanding and promoted collaborations among theory, computation and experimental researchers, and stimulated better communications among all members of the molecular- thermodynamics community. Together the participants analyzed the needs and challenges in connecting existing computational methods to the engineering reality, and discussed potential strategies to meet the global energy and environmental demands. In addition, they presented examples and envisioned the pivotal role that molecular thermodynamics must play to accelerate development of innovative sustainable technologies.

The workshop served at least three purposes. First, it stimulated debates and discussion among scholars from different camps of the molecular thermodynamics community on future research directions, in particular the importance and impact of experimentation, computation and machine learning on inverse product design and new industrial applications. Second, it provided valuable inputs into science policy thinking to support fundamental research that addresses key technological challenges. And third, it promoted interdisciplinary and international communication and collaboration by integrating experimental and computational methods into a more directed and fruitful way for engineering design and optimization.
